<p style="text-align:justify">In simple words Related Party Transactions (RPTs) are those transactions that a Company does with the parties related to it directly or indirectly through its Promoters, Directors, Key Managerial Persons and, Relatives of Promoters, Directors and Key Managerial Persons. However, RPTs are usually not simple but the most complicated and sensitive transactions from the point of view of the Company’s operations & its corporate governance. RPTs are generally the crux of any fraud/misdoings happening inside the Company.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Various provisions have been enacted under various act/ regulations to address the issue related to the misdoings happening due to RPTs and to regulate the RPTs by putting restrictions, conditions of pre-approval, pre & post transaction disclosures/ compliances, etc. A brief overview of RPTs and provisions related to it are being covered herein.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who is a Related Party?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">As per the provisions of the Section 2(76) of the Companies Act, 2013 (“the Act”) and Rule 3 of Companies (Specification of definitions details) Rules, 2014, a Related Party, with reference to a company means the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Director, KMP or any of their relatives;
	</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Firm, or Private Limited Company in which a Director, Manager or his relative is a partner, member or director;
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A public company in which a Director or Manager is a Director and holds along with his relatives, more than two per cent of its paid-up share capital;
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate whose Board of Directors, Managing Director or Manager is accustomed to act in accordance with the advice, directions or instructions of a Director or Manager (excluding advice, directions or instructions given in a professional capacity);
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any person on whose advice, directions or instructions a Director or Manager is accustomed to act (excluding advice, directions or instructions given in a professional capacity);
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Director other than an Independent Director or KMP of the holding company or any of his relatives (shall be deemed to be a related party)
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is a Holding, Subsidiary or Associate Company of such Company
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is a Sister concern i.e. a subsidiary company of a holding company to which it is also a subsidiary
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is an Investing Company or Venturer Company (which means a body corporate whose investment in the company would result in the company becoming an associate company of the body corporate)
		<p>
			In addition to the above persons, following shall also be deemed to be a Related Party as per the SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015, applicable only for Listed Entities:
		</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any person or entity belonging to the promoter or promoter group of the listed entity and holding 20% or more shareholding in the listed entity
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<em>[Point Nos. (vii), (viii) & (ix) above are not applicable to a Private Limited Company]</em>
</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Further, a Relative with reference to any person, means anyone who is related to another, if:</p>
<ol type="i">
<li style="text-align:justify">they are members of a Hindu Undivided Family;</li> 
<li style="text-align:justify">they are husband and wife; or</li>
<li style="text-align:justify">one person is related to the other in the manner mentioned below:</li>
	<ol type="a">
		<li style="text-align:justify">Father (including step-father)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Mother (including step-mother)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Son (including step-son)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Son’s wife</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Daughter</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Daughter’s husband</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Brother (including step-brother)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Sister (including step-sister)</li>
	</ol>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Transactions considered as RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	RPTs are not prohibited but prior consent of the Board of Directors is required for all RPTs (including approval of Audit Committee in case of Listed Entities and those entities who are required to constitute an Audit Committee). Further consent of shareholders is also required for RPTs exceeding the thresholds prescribed for each such RPT in Section 188 of the Act and Rule 15 of the Companies (Meetings of Board and its Powers) Rules, 2014.
</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	Following are the transactions which are considered as Related Party Transactions:
</p>

<table width="100%" border="1" cellspacing="0" class="MsoTableGrid" style="border-collapse:collapse; border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;">
	<tbody>		
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top"><strong>Related Party Transactions (requiring prior consent of Board of Directors)</strong></td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top"><strong>Thresholds which if exceeded require approval of shareholders of the Company</strong></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">a. Sale/ Purchase/ Supply of any goods or materials</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Sale/ Purchase/ Supply of any goods or materials directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">b. Selling/ otherwise Disposing/ Buying property of any kind</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Selling/ otherwise Disposing/ Buying property of any kind directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the networth of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">c. Leasing of property of any kind</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Leasing of property of any kind <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">d. Availing/ Rendering of any services</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Availing/ Rendering of any services directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">e. Appointing of any agent for any of the above purposes</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Thresholds covered in point nos. a, b & d above.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">f. Such related party's appointment to any office or place of profit in the company, its subsidiary company or associate company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Such related party's appointment to any office or place of profit in the company, its subsidiary company or associate company is at <b>a monthly remuneration exceeding Rupees Two Lakhs Fifty Thousand</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">g. Underwriting the subscription of any securities or derivatives thereof, of the company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Underwriting the subscription of any securities or derivatives thereof, of the company <b>exceeding 1% of the networth of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<em>
		[Note:<br>
		1. Thresholds specified in point nos. a to d above shall apply for transaction(s) to be entered into either individually or taken together with the previous transactions during a financial year.<br>
		2. Turnover or Networth referred to in above threshold limits shall be computed on the basis of the Audited Financial Statements of the preceding Financial Year.]
	</em>
</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>General Conditions/ Requirements & exemptions for RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">No approval (either of Board of Directors or Shareholders of the Company) is required for transactions entered into by the Company in its ordinary course of business and which are at arm’s length price.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">No approval of Board of Directors required for RPTs entered into between a Holding Company and its Wholly Owned Subsidiary whose accounts are consolidated with such Holding Company and placed before the shareholders at the general meeting for approval.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Any member who is a related party shall not vote on the transaction for which he is a related party. However, the same shall not be applicable to a Private Limited Company and a Company in which 90% or more members (in numbers) are relatives of promoters or are related parties. </li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Any Director who is interested in any contract/ arrangement/ transaction (as specified in the Section 184 of the Act) shall not participate in the Board Meeting where such contract/ arrangement/ transaction is discussed. However, in case of a Private Limited Company, such a Director may participate in the discussion after giving disclosure of his interest in the said contract/ arrangement/ transaction.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">In case the contract or arrangement is entered into by a Director/ any other employee without prior consent of Board or the members of the company and is subsequently not ratified by the Board of Directors or the shareholders of the Company, as the case may be, within 3 months of from the date on which such transaction is entered, such transaction shall be voidable at the option of Board or members, as the case may be and if the contract or arrangement is with a Related Party to any Director, or is authorised by any other Director, the Directors concerned shall indemnify the Company against any loss incurred by it.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The Company can proceed against a Director or any employee who had entered into a contract/ arrangement in contravention of the provisions of the Act for recovery of any loss sustained by it as a result of such contract/ arrangement.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>Compliances for RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Agenda of the Board Meeting & explanatory statement annexed with the notice of general meeting of the Company shall disclose the details such as name of Related Party, nature of relationship with the Related Party, duration of contract/ arrangement, material terms of the contract/ arrangement including the value, if any and any other information relevant for the Directors or the Shareholders of the Company to take decision on the proposed transaction.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Details of every RPT must be reported in the Annual Board’s Report to the Shareholders along with justification for entering into RPTs.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">All Directors shall provide disclosure of their interests in other companies/ concerns/ firms in Form MBP-1 every year in the first Board Meeting he attends and whenever there is a change in his interests previously disclosed by him.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Company shall maintain a Register in Form MBP-4 for entering particulars of RPTs.</li> 
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>Role of Audit Committee in RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">In case of Listed Entities and Companies who are required to constitute an Audit Committee, Audit Committee plays a vital role in approval and subsequent modifications of RPTs. All RPTs shall require approval of the Audit Committee and the Audit Committee may make Omnibus approval for RPTs proposed to be entered into by the Company subject to certain conditions specified in the Act:</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Audit Committee shall consider repetitiveness of the transactions (in past or in future) and justification for the need of omnibus approval while specifying criteria for making omnibus approval. </li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Omnibus approval shall contain all such necessary information with respect to the transaction. However, where the need of RPT cannot be foreseen and details of RPT are not available, Audit Committee may make Omnibus approval for such transactions for an amount not exceeding INR 1,00,00,000 (Rupees One Crore) per transaction.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Omnibus approval shall be valid for one financial year only and fresh approval shall be required after the expiry of such financial year. It shall not be applicable for transactions of selling and disposing of the undertaking of the company.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Penalty for contravention of provisions of the Act in case of RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	Any Director/ any other employee who had entered into the contract/ arrangement with the Related Party in contravention of the provision of the Act, shall be liable to the following penalty:
</p>

<table width="100%" border="1" cellspacing="0" class="MsoTableGrid" style="border-collapse:collapse; border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">In case of Listed Company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">
				Imprisonment maximum up to one year; or<br>
				Fine not less than INR 25,000 maximum up to INR 5,00,000; or<br>
				Both with Imprisonment and Fine
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">In case of any other Company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Fine not less than INR 25,000 maximum up to INR 5,00,000</td>
		</tr>		
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Provisions of SEBI LODR Regulations related to RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Listed Entities shall be additionally required to comply with the following provisions of Securities and Exchange Board of India (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015 with respect to RPTs:</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Related Party Transaction means a transfer of resources, services or obligations between a listed entity and a Related Party, regardless of whether a price is charged and a transaction with a Related Party shall be construed to include a single transaction or a group of transactions in a contract.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Listed entities shall formulate a policy on materiality of RPTs and on dealing with the same (including clear threshold limits duly approved by the Board of Directors and such policy shall be reviewed by the Board of Directors at least once every 3 (Three) years & update accordingly) and publish the same on the website of the company. 
		<p>
			Material transaction shall mean transaction to be entered into individually or taken together with previous transactions during a financial year, exceeds 10% of the annual consolidated turnover of the listed entity as per the last audited financial statements.
		</p>
		<p>
			However, a transaction involving payments to related party with respect to brand usage or royalty shall be considered material if the transactions individually or taken together with previous transactions during a financial year, exceeds 5% of the annual consolidated turnover of the listed entity as per the last audited financial statements.
		</p>
	</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">All material RPTs shall require approval of the shareholders by way of passing an Ordinary Resolution and no Related Party shall approve such resolutions irrespective of whether the entity is a Related Party to the particular transaction or not.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">The listed entity shall submit disclosures of RPTs transactions on a consolidated basis, in the format specified in the relevant accounting standards for annual results to the stock exchanges and publish the same on its website within 30 days from the date of publication of its standalone and consolidated financial results for the half year.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Annual Report shall include disclosures in compliance with the Accounting Standard on “Related Party Disclosures”.</li> 
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Transfer Pricing effect on RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">RPTs are not governed by the conditions/ requirement specified by the Companies Act, 2013 or the SEBI regulations but also by Transfer Pricing regulations under the Income Tax Act, 1961 to prevent shifting out of profits from India by manipulating prices charged international transactions between Related Parties/ Associate Enterprises which results in erosion of tax base of India.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">In 2012 concept of Specified Domestic Transactions was introduced in Transfer Pricing Regulations to prevent tax mitigation in transactions entered into between domestic companies as well. So the basic purpose of Transfer Pricing regulation is to keep a check that International as well as Specified Domestic Transactions between Related Parties/ Associated Enterprises are done on an arm’s length basis and to curb tax arbitrage by shifting the profits within the group and reducing the overall tax burden of a group or a Company.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>International Transaction between two or more Associated Enterprises shall include:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">purchase, sale, transfer, lease or use of tangible property including building, transportation vehicle, machinery, equipment, tools, plant, furniture, commodity or any other article, product or thing;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">purchase, sale, transfer, lease or use of intangible property including the transfer of ownership or the provisions of use of rights regarding land use, copyrights, patents, trademarks, licences, franchises, customer list, marketing channel, brand, commercial secret, know-how, industrial property right, exterior design or practical and new design or any other business or commercial rights of similar nature;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">capital financing including any type of long-term or short-term borrowing, lending or guarantee, purchase or sale of marketable securities or any type of advance, payments or deferred payment or receivable or any other debt arising during the course of business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">provision of services including provision of market research, market development, marketing management, administration, technical service, repairs, design, consultation, agency, scientific research, legal or accounting service;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">a transaction of business restructuring or reorganization, entered into by an enterprise with Associated Enterprise, irrespective of the fact that it has bearing on the profit, income, losses or assets of such enterprises at the time of the transaction or at any future date.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Specified domestic transaction in case of an assessee shall mean any of the following transactions, not being an International Transaction:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transaction referred to in Section 80A of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transfer of goods or services referred to in Section 80IA(8) of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any business transacted between the assessee and the other person as referred to in Section 80IA(10) of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transaction referred to in any other Section under Chapter VI-A or Section 10AA of the Income Tax Act, 1961, to which provisions of Sections 80IA(8) or 80IA(10) are applicable; or</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any business transacted between the persons referred to in Section 115BAB(4) of the Income Tax Act, 1961</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">and where the aggregate of such transactions entered into by the assessee in the previous year exceeds a sum of INR 20 crore.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Associated Enterprise, in relation to another enterprise, means an enterprise:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">which participates, directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in the management or control or capital of the other enterprise; or</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">in respect of which one or more persons who participate, directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in its management or control or capital, are the same persons who participate directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in the management or control or capital of the other enterprise.</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Further, Section 92A(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961prescribes the criteria for considering two enterprises as deemed to be Associated Enterprises.</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Determination of Transfer Price should always be done at arm’s length price. Arm’s length price shall mean a price at which an entity shall transfer or sell goods or services to its associated enterprise at the same price at which it would have transferred or sold goods or services to any unrelated or unassociated independent enterprise.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		There are various methods, being the most appropriate method, for computation of arm’s length price as per Income Tax Act, 1961 which are as follows:
		<ol type="i">
			<li style="text-align:justify">comparable uncontrolled price method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">resale price method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">cost plus method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">profit split method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">transactional net margin method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">such other method as may be prescribed by the Board.</li>
		</ol>
		<p style="text-align:justify">The most appropriate method shall be applied for determination of arm’s length price in the manner as may be prescribed under the Income Tax Act or the Finance Act.</p>
		<p style="text-align:justify">Where more than one price is determined by the most appropriate method, the arm’s length price shall be taken to be the arithmetical mean of such prices. However, if the variation between the arm’s length price so determined and price at which the International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction has actually been undertaken does not exceed 3%, the price at which the International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction has actually been undertaken shall be deemed to be the arm’s length price.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Company shall maintain all records, information or document with respect to International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction as may be prescribed under the Income Tax Act, 1961. Failure to maintain all records, information or document shall attract a penalty of 2% of the total sum of transaction involved and failure to furnish the information or any document shall attract a penalty of INR 500/-.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Every Company who has entered into an International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction during the previous year shall obtain a report in Form 3CEB from an accountant and furnish such report on or before 30th November of the relevant Assessment Year.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Implication of Goods and Services Tax (GST) on RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Transactions between Related Persons for inadequate or no consideration shall be considered as supply and chargeable to GST under Schedule I of the GST Act. It is considered as supply only if such transaction happens in course or furtherance of business.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Related Person under GST:</u></p>
<ul type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Officer/ Director of one business is the Officer/ Director of another business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Legally recognized partners in business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Employer and Employee;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Person who directly or indirectly owns, controls or holds 25% or more of the outstanding voting stocks or shares or both;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">one of them directly or indirectly controls the other;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">both of them are directly or indirectly controlled by a third person;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">together they directly or indirectly control a third person; or</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">they are members of the same family;</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">The term person includes legal person as well.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Further, persons who are associated in the business of one another in that one is the sole agent or sole distributor or sole concessionaire, howsoever described, of the other, shall be deemed to be related.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Valuation:</u></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">The Government has notified various valuation rules for determining the value of supply in absence of consideration or in case of inadequate consideration for having a base for charging GST. However, if the buyer is eligible for full input tax credit, then the value of invoice will be considered as the value of transaction without any dispute, as it will be tax neutral for the GST Department and will have no impact of value being increased or decreased.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Conclusion:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">RPTs are governed and regulated by various set of statutes impacting corporate governance as well as taxation of a Company and therefore should be undertaken with utmost care, as RPTs, carry an inherent risk of transaction being done to favour or profit the Related Party which could result in causing harm to the interests of the Company’s shareholders. It does not only harm the interests of the shareholders but also of the other stakeholders like government, statutory authorities, banks, financial institutions, etc.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Honk Kong being the sixth livable city in Asia, has the potential to provide new business opportunities resulting in the growth of business and exploiting the other privileges offered by the country. Honk Kong, with a literacy rate of ‘ninety-six’ per cent has no shortage of skilled labor coupled. With excellent literacy rate, the computer literacy rate in the country is of ‘ninety-five’ per cent. Honk Kong with an international market has a privilege of bilingual population, people in Honk Kong are generally found with an acquaintance of mainly Cantonese or mandarin language and most important is that people here communicate in English making it easy for international businessmen. This location helps the employees to understand the culture followed by corporates in the mainland of China that provides the leeway to do business with China. Various advantages like tax exemption and extraction of funds by way of dividend, management fees and royalties paid to the businessmen incite to conduct business in the country. Honk Kong is said to have a particular administrative region of China and provide an opportunity to deal with one of the world’s largest economy in the world.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Honk Kong provides a market place of 450 million people with an easy access to China. Honk Kong is known’s as the highest source of investment to China. There is an excellent infrastructure set up in Hong Kong and the southern provinces of China including air, rail and road links. Hong Kong and China have signed the Closer Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA). This is a free trade agreement to provide Hong Kong’s manufacturers and supplier’s preferential access to the Chinese market. Hong Kong boasts the world’s 2nd best infrastructure in various forms such as seaport, a heavy scheduled cargo airport and advanced rail and road systems. As such, Hong Kong is usually considered as the preferred choice in Asia. Hong Kong’s location gives companies easy access to mainland China, Indian and Australian consumer markets. Many international banking companies and other service sector companies have their hubs based in Honk Kong. Hence any company willing to incorporate its base here does not experience financial obstructions due to such good financial centres. In 2015, ‘Business of Cities’ report released by Jones Lang Lasalle lists Hong Kong as the world’s 2nd most business-friendly city. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>INVESTMENT LAWS</strong></p>
</div>

<p style="text-align:justify">Nonresidents and foreign companies (including their branches) carrying on business in Hong Kong are treated in the same way as domestic companies. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">There is no distinction made between residents and non-residents when it comes to liability to profits tax.  A resident may therefore derive profits from abroad without being charged to tax; conversely, a non-resident may be chargeable to tax on profits arising in or derived from Hong Kong.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.gov.hk/en/nonresidents/investinghk/taxinhk.htm" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">
https://www.gov.hk/en/nonresidents/investinghk/taxinhk.htm</a></p>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 0in 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>ADVANTAGES OF INCORPORATING A BUSINESS IN HONK KONG</strong></p>
</div>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Amicable Incorporation Process</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">With a well structured legal system and transparent authorities working in the way of developing a liberal but organized environment for the incorporation of companies, it is claimed that a company in Honk Kong can be incorporated in the span of a week.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Structured Legislature</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">As the legislature is in compliance with the common law system, it increases the scope of incorporating a business plan in Honk Kong for not just the residents but also for foreigners as they will be well aware of the working process and administration of the legislature.<strong>  </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Minimum Requirement policy is applicable</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">As the incorporation process is amicable, it also provides the privilege to any person willing to set up business in Honk Kong. The privilege provided by the legislature is that a person can appoint one person as director and another individual person as a shareholder for the process of incorporation, more members are not required.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Corporate Tax</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Honk Kong charges one of the lowest taxes to corporates in Asia. The country charges the tax at the rate of 16.5% to corporates.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>No Language Barriers</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Though Chinese is one of the official languages in Honk Kong, English is preferred when it comes to doing business in the country. The documents in Honk Kong are in English and Chinese, which helps the foreigners in understanding the process without requiring any external support. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Foreign Investment State                                                 </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Resident companies can invest in any industry without government restrictions regardless of the nationalities of their owners. This is said to be one of the significant features where foreigners are willing to enter the Honk Kong market.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Treaties for Double Tax avoidance</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">In promoting the ease of doing business in Hong Kong, it holds double tax agreements (DTAs) with several countries. A double taxation Avoidance Agreement is a treaty entered between two countries for reducing the burden of paying double tax on the same income. It generally takes place between two countries where a person is earning income in one country and repatriating it in some other country. To avoid the confusion between the two countries on who will be the actual assessor of the person’s income this treaty is formulated. Due to Globalization business houses are going for expansion beyond the borders, it plays a significant role in deciding the net profit and net tax payable. Below is the list of countries that are a signatory with Hong Kong.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Opening of Bank Credit policy</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The city is ranked as the 4th best place in the world to get credit from the bank.<strong> </strong>Obtaining bank credit is relatively easy in Hong Kong which in turn helps in financing a corporate entity.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>TYPES OF ENTITIES IN HONK KONG</strong></p>
</div>
<p> </p>
<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Limited Company</strong></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Limited Companies in Honk Kong has non-restricted exposure; it can spread its operation as and when allowed by law in any sector that makes the limited company a more popular option as compared to any other options. Only on the overseas income, the privileges related to tax exemption will be enjoyed by the Limited Companies. Thus, it is always feasible to open/set-up/incorporate as holding a company or headquarters of the company. The process of opening a company is amicable in Honk Kong including:</p>

<ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha">
	<li style="text-align:justify">only one director (of any nationality)</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">only one shareholder (of any nationality)</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">A Resident Secretary.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">As for long, major countries are complying with English laws stating the corporate. Once the register is said to be a distinct entity to its promoters, Honk Kong incorporates the same policies. Therefore it is easier to inculcate the administrative rules of corporate in Honk Kong. The corporate directors are not allowed under Hong Kong company law, whereas, the corporate shareholders are common. No specific approval is required for the purpose of incorporating the limited liability company from Honk Kong government and no pre-required capital requirement is the condition for the process of setting up a limited company. There is no restriction on capital denomination invested in Honk Kong; a person willing to incorporate limited company can invest in any denomination, i.e. USD, EURO, HKD, etc.</p>
<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>	
<ol start="2">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Branch Office</strong></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">A branch office is basically an extension of the registered business working under the control of the company. A branch office has no separate legal entity. Any positive or negative effect on the income of the company shall be attributed to the parent company. A set up of the branch office in Honk Kong can conduct trade and business in the scope set by the parent company. Any business required to be conducted will be restricted by the legislature to the limits of Honk Kong along with appropriate license in this behalf. Any company registering a branch office in Honk Kong will be allowed to start trading or conduct any other business activities a month prior to the actual registration. Any foreigners setting up a company is required to register with the registry and any person setting up branch office needs to register as NON-Honk Kong Registered branch Office. The set-up of branch offices is allowed to conduct all such activities mentioned in law on behalf of Company such as signing the contracts or any other documents validating the transaction, etc. After considering the various advantages, it is feasible for the company to start its business immediately. The advantage of starting the branch offices is that it is not necessary for them to submit its audited financial statements for any purpose.</p>
<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>
<ol start="3">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Representative Office</strong></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">As per the rules and regulations of Hong Kong, no company having representative status will be allowed to make any direct sales in the country. It can engage in the following activities:</p>

<ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Promoting the parent company’s business.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Conduct market research.</li>
</ol>

<p> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any company having status as the representative office to provide local services, such offices should be incorporated in Honk Kong. </p>

<p> </p>

<ol start="4">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Offshore Company in Honk Kong</strong></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">It’s of great advantage to any company to house or invest funds or gain profit in Honk Kong by setting up an offshore company and repatriate funds by receiving the benefits of minimal tax policy. There would be a 100% tax exemption to any company who hasn’t conducted any transaction. An offshore company can quickly set up in the country like Hong Kong. For the process of incorporation of the company, it requires only one director and one shareholder. Both can be of any nationality. Incorporation of the company takes one week. Hong Kong’s banking system is considered as one of the most secure in the world and the government has strong client confidentiality guidelines. Setting up an offshore company in Hong Kong is not considered as a tax avoidance strategy and as such, it is easy to open corporate bank accounts. </p>
<p> </p>
<ol start="5">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Subsidiary Company</strong></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any company incorporated as a private limited company under the holding company conducting its performance in a different sector or same sector is known as the subsidiary company. Laws governing the corporate and other matters relevant to companies, provide the investment limits up to 100% foreign money in a company.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">With numerous tax advantages and other benefits, it became a necessary measure to incorporate the subsidiary company. As the limited liability principle is applicable in Honk Kong, the debts or any liability will not be applicable to its parent company. Any company incorporated by a parent company will have the advantage to achieve its growth in the Chinese markets.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><br />
<strong>Following are the basic requirements for registering a Subsidiary Company </strong></p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Approval of the company name</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Local registered address</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">At least one director and shareholder</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">A local resident company secretary and an auditor</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The company must have share capital but there is no minimum requirement. </li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">For taxation purposes, a subsidiary is treated as a Hong Kong resident company and is eligible for tax exemptions and incentives applicable to the local companies.</li>
</ul>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>PROCEDURE FOR INCORPORATING COMPANY IN HONG KONG</strong></p>
</div>
<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>
<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Name of the Company</strong> – The company name must be approved before proceeding with the incorporation process of a Hong Kong company.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="2">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Ordinance of the Companies </strong>– As per the amendment, effective from 1 March 2018, every company incorporated in Hong Kong, except for those listed in the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE), will be required to create and maintain a register of all persons who have significant control of the company. A Designated Representative (DR) must be appointed by the companies, who will be responsible for reporting to the prescribed local authorities about the reports relating to SCR upon their demand.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="3">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Directors </strong>– A minimum of one individual director and the unlimited number of directors are allowed in the formation of the company. The director must be a natural person who can be of any nationality and need not be a resident of Hong Kong. Directors must have completed at least 18 years of his/her age and must not be convicted for any malpractices or bankrupt. There is no requirement for the directors to also be the shareholders. In addition to the individual director, nominee corporate directors can also be appointed. The Directors Board meetings can be held anywhere in the world.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="4">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Shareholders</strong> – In Hong Kong, a private limited company can have minimum one shareholder and a maximum of 50 shareholders. There is no residency requirement for the shareholders. A director and shareholder can be the same or different person. The shareholder must have completed at least 18 years of age and can belong to any country. The shareholder can be a person or a company. The company law allows 100% local or foreign shareholding. Appointment of the nominee shareholders is permitted. The meetings of shareholders can be conducted anywhere in the world.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify">                      </p>

<ol start="5">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Company Secretary</strong> – Appointment of a company secretary is mandatory. The secretary, if an individual must ordinarily reside in Hong Kong; or if a body corporate must have its registered office or a place of business in Hong Kong. It has to be noted that the same person cannot act as the company secretary, in case of a sole director/shareholder. The company secretary is responsible for maintaining the statutory books and all other records of the company. The Secretary must also ensure the compliance of the company with all statutory requirements. A nominee secretary can be appointed.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="6">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Share Capital </strong>– Although there is no requirement of minimum share capital, the general norms for the incorporation of companies in Hong Kong is to have at least one shareholder with one ordinary share issued for the formation of the company. Share capital can be expressed in any major currency and is not restricted to the Hong Kong Dollar. Shares can be transferred freely, subject to the stamp duty fee. Bearer shares are not allowed.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="7">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Registered Address </strong>– In order to register a Hong Kong company, it is necessary to provide a local (Hong Kong) address as the registered address of the company. The registered address must be a physical address and cannot be a PO Box.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="8">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Public Information </strong>– As per the Company laws of Hong Kong, any information about company officers viz. directors, shareholders and company secretary is public. It is mandatory to file details of the company officers with the Hong Kong Registrar of Companies. If any company wishes to maintain confidentiality, it can appoint a corporate shareholder and a nominee individual director by utilizing the services of a professional services firm.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="9">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Taxation </strong>– Corporate tax, (or profits tax as it is called), is set at 16.5% of assessable profits for companies set up in Hong Kong. Hong Kong follows taxation on a territorial basis, i.e. only profits which arise or derived from Hong Kong are subject to tax in Hong Kong. There is no capital gains tax, withholding tax on dividends, or GST/VAT in Hong Kong.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="10">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><strong>Ongoing Compliance</strong> – It is mandatory for companies to prepare and maintain accounts. Accounts must be audited annually by Certified Public Accountants. The audited accounts together with tax return must be filed annually with the Inland Revenue Department. It is necessary for every company to file annual returns with the Companies Registry and pay the annual registration fee. The Business Registration Certificate should be renewed, one month before expiry on an annual basis or once every three years, as the case may be. An Annual General Meeting (AGM) should be held annually every calendar year. The AGM should be held within 18 months of the date of incorporation, after which no more than 15 months can elapse between one AGM and the next. A written resolution in lieu of the Annual General Meeting is permissible.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:24px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Usually, it takes about 5-7 working days to incorporate a company in Hong Kong. Following points are to be considered by any person who is willing to incorporate an offshore company:</p>

<ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha">
	<li style="text-align:justify">There are no local resident requirements; an offshore can be set up by sole directors.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Every bank may have different rules and regulation, although no physical presence is required at times of incorporation of the company, it is always preferable to be present at the time of opening of a bank account.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Any foreigners willing to operate his/her business from overseas can do if he/she chooses not to relocate his business in Honk Kong.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>DOCUMENTS REQUIRED FOR INCORPORATION </strong></p>
</div>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any person who wishes to incorporate a company in Honk Kong needs to comply with the documentation required to fill in the registrar </p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">A copy of the Articles of Association for the company. A standard document normally provided by the professional services firm who is assisting with the incorporation of the company.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="2">

	<li style="text-align:justify">  Copy of passport, overseas residential address proof</li>
</ul>

<ol start="4">
	<li style="text-align:justify">For resident shareholders and directors:</li>
</ol>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Copy of Hong Kong identity card</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Copy of residential address proof</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left:96px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="5">
	<li style="text-align:justify">For corporate shareholders and directors:</li>
</ol>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Copy of parent company registration documents such as Certificate of Incorporation and Articles of Association</li>
</ul>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>IP IN HONG KONG</strong></p>
</div>

<p style="text-align:justify">An intangible asset that is the result of creativity results in forming of Intangible asset. An intellectual property right is the right of a person on his/her creativity, and it is important for a person to protect such property from being copied/ plagiarized. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>IP schemes</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Working Group on Intellectual Property (IP) Trading releases report for driving the development of Hong Kong as an IP trading hub. The Intellectual Property Department of the Government of the Hong Kong SAR, with support from the Law Society of Hong Kong, provides FREE One-On-One IP Consultation Service for Hong Kong small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with a view to assisting Hong Kong SMEs to raise their awareness of intellectual property (IP), as well as to develop effective IP management and commercialization strategies and to deal with possible challenges in the competitive environment
.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.ip.gov.hk/en/resources/policy-initiatives.html" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.ip.gov.hk/en/resources/policy-initiatives.html</a> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.ip.gov.hk/en/resources/free-consultation-service.html" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.ip.gov.hk/en/resources/free-consultation-service.html</a></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Following are the protection allowed by Hong Kong authorities in case of Intellectual Property</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Patents </li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:justify">Any new/ innovative steps introduce by someone that can be acknowledged or acceptable in terms of industrial application can be termed as a trademark. Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) provides only territorial protection to trademark. Any person needs to follow two-stage application processes in case of registration patent first application of patent and grant of patent. Standard HKSAR provides a protection of patent for the period of 20 years and then patent is applicable for registration. (A standard patent will last for a maximum term of 20 years, subject to the payment of renewal fees. A short-term patent will last for a maximum term of 8 years subject to the payment of renewal fees.)</p>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="2">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Copyrights</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any type of literally work or artistic work by a person will be granted protection under the Berne Convention, the WIPO Copyright Treaty and the WIPO Performance and Phonograms Treaty to the HKSAR. The duration of copyright of literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works is the life of the author plus 50 years. </p>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="3">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Trademark</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">A trademark is a sign that distinguishes the goods and services of one trader from those of others. Typically a trademark can be words (including personal names), indications, designs, letters, characters, numerals, figurative elements, colours, sounds, smells, the shape of the goods or their packaging or any combination of these. A sign must be capable of being represented graphically in order for it to be registered as a trademark. A registered trademark is valid for ten years from the filing date and is renewable indefinitely for further periods of 10 years each by paying the renewal fee. Trademarks in Hong Kong may be renewed within six months before the expiry of the validity term but not later than six months after its expiry.</p>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="4">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Layout out Design</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any person inventing a news design for layout will be provided protection under the Layout-design (Topography) of Integrated Circuits Ordinance any person copying the design will be held liable and civil action can be taken against. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The duration of layout-design (topography) of integrated circuits protection depends upon whether such layout-design (topography) is commercially exploited. If a layout-design (topography) has not been commercially exploited anywhere in the world, the term of the protection will end 15 years after the end of the year in which it was created. On the other hand, if a layout-design (topography) has been commercially exploited anywhere in the world, the term of the protection will end 10 years after the end of the year in which it was first commercially exploited.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">However, a registered trademark may be challenged in revocation proceedings if it is not used in Hong Kong for a continuous period of 3 years.</p>

<ol start="5">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Plant varieties protection </li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any person who is a plant breeder for a specific variety of plant can authorize others to reproduce his/her new plant variety. The Plant Varieties Protection Ordinance provides the protection for plant breeders. In Hong Kong, subject to the payment of annual grant fees, the right of a plant variety shall be in force for a period of:</p>

<ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha">
	<li style="text-align:justify">25 years in the case of trees and vines, and</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">20 years in every other case.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="6">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Trade Secrets</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Trade secrets are the confidential information that have future economic benefit relating to a commercial transaction. In HKSAR, trade secrets are protected by the common law of confidence. The protection of trade secrets can be done by any person if he/she is of the opinion that the protection provided by patent law is not enough.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="7">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Registered Design </li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any new shape, pattern or ornaments applied to any article that resulted in the making of a new design or a unique product can be protected under the Registered Designs Ordinance, any person plagiarizing or producing a same or similar product will be held liable for the act. The producer of the design can take civil action against the person who copied or plagiarized the design. The registration of a design lasts for five years beginning from the filing date. It may be extended for additional periods of five years, up to a maximum of 25 years from the filing date.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Hong Kong has a robust IP environment. It is a part of several international treaties to accommodate international filings.</p>

<div style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in">
<p style="margin-left:48px; text-align:justify"><strong>TAX STRUCTURE IN HONK KONG</strong></p>
</div>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Profits Tax Rate</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Normal Rate</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Two-tier rates: </p>

<ol style="list-style-type:lower-roman">
	<li style="text-align:justify">For corporations, the first HK$2 million of profits earned by a company will be taxed at half the current tax rate (i.e., 8.25%) whilst the remaining profits will continue to be taxed at the existing 16.5% tax rate on assessable profits. </li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">(The <strong>Assessable Profits </strong>{or Adjusted Loss} are the net profits {or loss} for the basis period, arising in or derived from Hong Kong, calculated in accordance with the provisions of Part IV of the I.R.O.)</p>

<ol start="2" style="list-style-type:lower-roman">
	<li style="text-align:justify">For unincorporated businesses, the first HK$2 million of profits earned will be taxed at half of the current tax rate (i.e., 7.5%) whilst the remaining profits thereafter will be taxed at the existing 15% tax rate.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:114px; text-align:justify"> </p>

<ol start="2">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Concessionary Rate</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">A concessionary tax rate is available only for certain qualifying profits.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">A concessionary tax rate at 50% of the normal profits tax rate will be applied to trading profits and interest income received or derived from Qualifying debt instruments (QDIs - <a href="https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_qdi.htm" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_qdi.htm</a>) issued in Hong Kong, and to offshore business of professional reinsurance companies. The profits from QDIs, which are already taxed at 8.25% or 7.5%, would not be counted towards the HK$2 million threshold for the purpose of applying the two-tier rates. That means businesses with assessable profits derived from QDIs can continue to enjoy the half rate on all such profits and at the same time, their first HK$2 million of assessable profits that are not derived from QDIs will be taxed at 8.25% or 7.5%.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">All taxpayers are subject to the same corporation or unincorporated business tax rate irrespective of their residential status.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_pft.htm#a10" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_pft.htm#a10</a></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Provisional Profits tax </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Profit tax is chargeable on the assessable profits for each year of assessment. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">As the assessable profits for any particular year cannot be known until after the end of the year concerned, a provisional tax charge has to be raised. When the assessable profits for the year of assessment are subsequently ascertained, an assessment will be made and the provisional profits tax paid will be utilized to offset the tax liability under the assessment.</p>

<p>One may apply in writing for holding over of the whole or part of the provisional tax on the grounds as specified in the Inland Revenue Ordinance. Here you can learn more about the time limit, methods and grounds for application for holding over of provisional tax.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Time Limit for Application</p>

<p>Your application for holding over of provisional tax should be lodged not later than:</p>

<ul>
	<li>28 days before the due date for payment of the provisional tax, or</li>
	<li>14 days after the date of issue of the notice for payment of the provisional tax,</li>
</ul>

<p>whichever is later.</p>

<p>If the provisional tax is payable by two installments and the first installment has been settled by the due date, an application for holding over of the whole or part of the second installment may be made subject to the prescribed time limit and grounds for application.  Details about the time limit for applying for holdover of provisional tax can be found in the following link.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/faq/hpt.htm#a8" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline" title="Frequently asked questions about time limit for applying for holdover of provisional tax">
Frequently asked questions about time limit for applying for holdover of provisional tax</a></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_pft.htm#a05" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.ird.gov.hk/eng/tax/bus_pft.htm#a05</a></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Withholding tax</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Is a tax applicable to residents and non-residents on earning any income from shares or other securities by way of dividend or interest. With liberal tax policy in Hong Kong there are no taxes applicable to residents and non-residents. There is no withholding tax on dividend distributions, interest payments, technical service fees and branch remittance tax from a Hong Kong entity to a resident or nonresident. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">However, Royalties and fees paid to non-resident entertainers or sportsmen for their performances in Hong Kong are subject to withholding tax on their assessable profits. Generally, the withholding tax rate for royalty payments due to a non-resident company that is an associate of the Hong Kong entity is 16.5%.
 The objective behind levying a 16.5% withholding tax rate is to prevent taxpayers from minimizing their Hong Kong tax liability by entering into arrangements with associated companies or individuals. However, it must be noted that the withholding tax rate of 16.5% is restricted in its application. It does not apply to royalty payments made to an associate Hong Kong company or individual if the Inland Revenue Department is satisfied that “no person carrying on a trade, profession or business in Hong Kong has at any time wholly or partly-owned the relevant intellectual property.” In such cases a reduced withholding tax rate of 4.95% will apply.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="https://www.guidemehongkong.com/business-guides/supporting-a-business/hong-kong-withholding-tax-guide" style="color:blue; text-decoration:underline">https://www.guidemehongkong.com/business-guides/supporting-a-business/hong-kong-withholding-tax-guide</a></p>

<p>Royalty payments include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Payments received from the exhibition or use of films, tape recordings, sound recordings, or any related advertising materials in Hong Kong;</li>
	<li>Payments received for the use of or right to use any patent, design, trademark, copyright material, secret formula or other similar property in or outside Hong Kong; or</li>
	<li>Payments received for imparting knowledge connected with the use of intellectual property in or outside Hong Kong.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Real Property Tax</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any person acquiring a property on rent will be liable to pay tax at the standard rate of 15%. It is calculated on the net assessable value of the property; however there is no capital gains tax. For capital expenditure on refurbishment of business premises, it is possible to write it off over a five-year assessment period. For plant and machinery, an initial 60% deduction is allowed for the capital expenditure, whereas, 20% of the written down value can be deducted for each year. 100% deduction is allowed for computer hardware and software, while 20% deduction each for five consecutive years is allowed for refurbishment expenses.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Social Security</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) is a compulsory saving scheme (pension fund) designed by the Hong Kong government as a major protection scheme for aged and retired residents. According to the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) Ordinance, the employee will join the employer's MPF Scheme automatically after completing 60 working days. Employers and employees are each required to make regular mandatory contributions of 5% of the employee’s relevant income to an MPF scheme, subject to the minimum and maximum relevant income levels. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Any other taxes such as capital duty, payroll taxes and transfer tax are not applicable to residents and non-residents.    </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Stamp Duty </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Stamp duty is charged on documents connected with the lease, sale or transfer of immovable property and the sale of shares in Hong Kong. If property or shares are sold for less than the market value, stamp duty may be imposed based on the market value on the date of the transfer. The rate on the lease of immovable property starts at 0.25 percent of the total rent payable and stamp duty on the transfer of Hong Kong shares is 0.20 percent of the value of the shares transferred (which is shared by the seller and the buyer)</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Other Taxes</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Other taxes such as alternative minimum tax, surtax and VAT are not applicable to resident and non-resident.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"> </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Treatment of losses</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Losses made in an accounting year can be carried forward and set off against future profits of that trade. To qualify for deduction, losses should have arisen during the course of carrying on a business in Hong Kong. Losses can be carried forward indefinitely until they are fully utilized, subject to certain conditions such as no substantial change in shareholders.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Section 19C of the Inland Revenue Ordinance deals with the treatment of losses arising from a trade, profession or business. Section 19 C (6) makes it clear that a loss cannot be set off more than once and that the total amount set off against assessable profits is not to exceed the amount of loss. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify">It is necessary to understand all compliance requirements for Hong Kong Companies to steer away any legal problems. Following are the points required to be followed by the private limited companies:</p>
